result.markdown:
---
title: "Statistical models: linking data to theory"
---

## Setup environment


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
library(easystats)
library(ggformula)
```
:::


## Class 1: Introduction

<https://youtu.be/b2PyeRu53OU>

What is a statistical model?

A statistical model is a mathematical representation of a process that generates data, according to some theory.

Thus, a statistical model is a way to link data to theory, i.e., a hypothesis about how a given data set was generated.

Deterministic vs stochastic mathematical model.

## Class 2: Statistical models

XXX

## Generalized linear models


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(titanic)
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
m0 <- glm(Survived ~ 1, data = titanic_train, family = binomial)

summary(m0)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

Call:
glm(formula = Survived ~ 1, family = binomial, data = titanic_train)

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error z value        Pr(>|z|)    
(Intercept)  -0.4733     0.0689   -6.87 0.0000000000064 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

(Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)

    Null deviance: 1186.7  on 890  degrees of freedom
Residual deviance: 1186.7  on 890  degrees of freedom
AIC: 1189

Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plogis(parameters(m0)$Coefficient)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 0.3838
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mean(titanic_train$Survived)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 0.3838
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
qlogis(mean(titanic_train$Survived))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] -0.4733
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
m1 <- glm(Survived ~ 1 + Sex, data = titanic_train, family = binomial)

summary(m1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

Call:
glm(formula = Survived ~ 1 + Sex, family = binomial, data = titanic_train)

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error z value             Pr(>|z|)    
(Intercept)    1.057      0.129    8.19  0.00000000000000026 ***
Sexmale       -2.514      0.167  -15.04 < 0.0000000000000002 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

(Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)

    Null deviance: 1186.7  on 890  degrees of freedom
Residual deviance:  917.8  on 889  degrees of freedom
AIC: 921.8

Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
estimate_means(m1, "Sex")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Estimated Marginal Means

Sex    | Probability |       95% CI
-----------------------------------
female |        0.74 | [0.69, 0.79]
male   |        0.19 | [0.16, 0.22]

Variable predicted: Survived
Predictors modulated: Sex
Predictions are on the response-scale.
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
m2 <- glm(Survived ~ 1 + Sex + factor(Pclass), data = titanic_train, family = binomial)

summary(m2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

Call:
glm(formula = Survived ~ 1 + Sex + factor(Pclass), family = binomial, 
    data = titanic_train)

Coefficients:
                Estimate Std. Error z value             Pr(>|z|)    
(Intercept)        2.297      0.219   10.49 < 0.0000000000000002 ***
Sexmale           -2.642      0.184  -14.35 < 0.0000000000000002 ***
factor(Pclass)2   -0.838      0.245   -3.42              0.00062 ***
factor(Pclass)3   -1.905      0.214   -8.90 < 0.0000000000000002 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

(Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)

    Null deviance: 1186.66  on 890  degrees of freedom
Residual deviance:  826.89  on 887  degrees of freedom
AIC: 834.9

Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
estimate_means(m2, c("Sex", "Pclass"))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Estimated Marginal Means

Sex    | Pclass | Probability |       95% CI
--------------------------------------------
female |      1 |        0.91 | [0.87, 0.94]
male   |      1 |        0.41 | [0.34, 0.50]
female |      2 |        0.81 | [0.74, 0.87]
male   |      2 |        0.23 | [0.17, 0.31]
female |      3 |        0.60 | [0.52, 0.67]
male   |      3 |        0.10 | [0.07, 0.13]

Variable predicted: Survived
Predictors modulated: Sex, Pclass
Predictions are on the response-scale.
```


:::
:::
